body_html:
You could do "batch major broadcasting" the same way you do it for other TensorFlow ops: you would explicitly expand dimensions first, e.g., with tf.new_axis or tf.reshape.
…
On Thu, Oct 4, 2018 at 12:18 AM Martin Wicke ***@***.***> wrote: I see... if we believe that the two broadcasting modes should be accessible, we could alternative introduce an argument which switches the behavior. In 1.x, the default must be the current behavior, in 2.0 we could decide to switch the behavior, if we think consistency with numpy outweighs the utility argument. — You are receiving this because you commented. body_text:
You could do "batch major broadcasting" the same way you do it for other
TensorFlow ops: you would explicitly expand dimensions first, e.g., with
tf.new_axis or tf.reshape.
…
On Thu, Oct 4, 2018 at 12:18 AM Martin Wicke ***@***.***> wrote:
 I see... if we believe that the two broadcasting modes should be
 accessible, we could alternative introduce an argument which switches the
 behavior. In 1.x, the default must be the current behavior, in 2.0 we could
 decide to switch the behavior, if we think consistency with numpy outweighs
 the utility argument.

 —

body:
You could do "batch major broadcasting" the same way you do it for other
TensorFlow ops: you would explicitly expand dimensions first, e.g., with
tf.new_axis or tf.reshape.
On Thu, Oct 4, 2018 at 12:18 AM Martin Wicke <notifications@github.com>
wrote:

> I see... if we believe that the two broadcasting modes should be
> accessible, we could alternative introduce an argument which switches the
> behavior. In 1.x, the default must be the current behavior, in 2.0 we could
> decide to switch the behavior, if we think consistency with numpy outweighs
> the utility argument.
>
> —
> You are receiving this because you commented.
